Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the mother should provide guidance
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, laptop open, code editor glaring at me with a blinking cursor. My team’s messages kept popping up—“Any update on the module?”—and I knew the project was at a standstill until I finished. My son, meanwhile, was at the other end of the table, fidgeting with his spoon, refusing to eat his vegetables. He looked up at me, eyes searching for guidance, waiting for me to remind him about table manners and why we don’t waste food. I could hear my manager’s voice in my head, pressing for progress, and at the same time, my own mother’s voice, reminding me that teaching values starts at home, in these small moments. My heart tugged in two directions: the urgency of my team’s reliance on me, and the quiet, persistent need to be present for my child, to shape him into a kind, disciplined person. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding my full attention, and I sat there, torn, unsure which role to answer first.
